rename.from: "undefined is not an object" on drag
rename.to: "undefined is not an object" if elements removed during d3.behavior.drag

body:
> Personally I'm not super excited with the current drag implementation overall … most notably its handling for multiple fingers is broken in general

What’s the problem, exactly? It seems to work for me: http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/9631744

Although I do see an issue where if you lift one finger, the other fingers stop tracking. I recall seeing this before and I’m not sure if there’s a way to fix it or if it’s a simple bug in the drag behavior.

Also: http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/9631063

issue.title: Better multitouch.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
This fixes a bug where all touches would ending on any touch ending.

The drag behavior registers a touchend listener for each started touch; however, a touchend event is dispatched to ALL listeners when any touch ends, not just for the corresponding starting touch. The drag behavior must therefore detect whenever the ending touch is the corresponding starting touch, and ignore other ending touches.

This fixes the drag behavior during multitouch, as discussed in #1786.

issue.title: The scope of d3.behavior.drag?

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
This ticket follows a rabbit trail off of #1786

Backstory: I'm using `d3.behavior.drag` basically as a cross-platform foundation (Pointer Events pull request planned ;-) for a feature that ends up being like `d3.svg.brush` but within HTML and would also love to have something even more generic for general touch wrapping.

It's clear that the intended use is more of a "drag a target around" than my use case (e.g. I'm having to fix up the origin so that I get locations _within_ the target rather than its parent) and for having a general multitouch handler there's some other missing/broken pieces. I'm wondering if this is "in scope" for d3.behavior.drag or maybe I should just be using [PointerEvents polyfill](https://github.com/Polymer/PointerEvents).

One of the "core" problems with d3.behavior.drag multitouch is that the touchend handler doesn't pay attention to which touch was ended. But that leads back to a few other assumptions: that the drag is meant to be called on a moveable child (rather than a brush-like parent situation, which would need to _distinguish_ between events from different fingers and has to manually fix up origin), that only one finger will "touchstart" at once, that "touchcancel" won't get called…

Kind of a laundry list, and don't mean to sound like I'm griping — for practical purposes once I worked around #1388 (which is not really the behavior's fault) it is working for my main case right now. Just trying to figure out what my long-term "go-to" tool should be for this stuff: d3.behavior.drag, PointerEvents polyfill, or make a third-party "pointers behavior" plugin…

body:
Whoops, filed #1793 while you were fixing some of the tangential issues mentioned here. One other thing I noticed about your http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/9631744 is that after moving a bubble once I can't move it again — haven't diagnosed.

I would agree this ticket is basically a duplicate of #1388 with the added note that drag events not only cease but the internal state becomes exception-prone, sorry I didn't find that one originally.
[bl.ocks.org/9631744](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/9631744) isn’t running the fix in #1792 (because that code hasn’t been released yet).

This is different from #1388. That issue is regarding the zoom behavior rather than the drag behavior, and it isn’t a bug as much as a gotcha that needs documentation; if you remove the element that was the target of a touchstart, you no longer receive touchmove and touchend events. (As shown in [bl.ocks.org/770ae19ca830a4ce87f5](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/raw/770ae19ca830a4ce87f5/).) This is appears to be a limitation of WebKit, and the recommended workaround is to use an overlay so that the event target is never removed during a zoom gesture.

This bug, in contrast, can be fixed in the drag behavior. I’m not sure exactly what the fix will entail, but the desired behavior is that the drag behavior stops dragging if the drag target is removed. :)

Ah, forgot that was zoom. Then yes, perhaps the short-circuit to `ended()` if the id isn't found in my OP would work for your intended behavior.

BTW, this isn't really a "WebKit" thing per-se, the W3C spec dictates that touchmove/touchend events are always "captured" by the original (touchstart) element. So if that element is removed, the move/end events are still _dispatched_, they just may not bubble up to the original parent.
Ah ha. That’s interesting. That would suggest that the touchmove and touchend events should be assigned to the target element on touchstart then, I suppose?

I’ve updated my example here http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/770ae19ca830a4ce87f5

Now I wonder whether the zoom behavior should listen to the touchstart target rather than the container… probably?
Marking this as fixed since it is now covered by #1792.

issue.title: behavior.zoom on multi touch (android) locks up

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Hi,

I'm experiencing an issue with a tree graph based on: 

http://bl.ocks.org/robschmuecker/7880033

I'm using chrome for android, but it also seems to happen in firefox for android. D3 version is 3.4.6.

The problem seems to occur when I start panning my layout with the first touch being over a node. When I add a second finger outside of the node (but inside the svg) and let go of the first touch, the zoom behavior stops working (except for doubletap zoom). The only way to get the zoom behavior back, is by starting it on the initial node, or manualy readding the svg.on('zoom', zoom).

I think the problem is caused by the last touch event not having the same target as the initial touch.
I've read some suggestions where pointer event are captured by an overlay to make sure everything has the same target, however I need my nodes to be clickable. 

Using zoomstart and zoomend events to dynamically add an overlay doesn't seem to work because the overlay gets added at the first touch, so my nodes still aren't clickable.

I managed to replicate the error in the above example, by pressing on the root node, placing my 2nd finger to the left of the graph and lifting my first finger.
